commit_message:
Make sure octavia uses internal endpoint to barbican

The octavia service communicates to the barbican service with
public endpoint_type by default[1], it should use internal
like other services.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/octavia/blob/0056b5175f89070164849501ec6d960549b95e34/octavia/common/config.py#L533-L537

Closes-Bug: #1875618
Change-Id: I90d2b0aeac090a3e2366341e260232fc1f0d6492
(cherry picked from commit 01ae01ec26769d15059a45432c8accffc10f0da1)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/12/724212/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - | Switch endpoint_type from public to internal for octavia communicating with the barbican service. See `bug 1875618 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/kolla-ansible/+bug/1875618>`__ for details.

commit_message:
Make sure octavia uses internal endpoint to barbican

The octavia service communicates to the barbican service with
public endpoint_type by default[1], it should use internal
like other services.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/octavia/blob/0056b5175f89070164849501ec6d960549b95e34/octavia/common/config.py#L533-L537

Closes-Bug: #1875618

(cherry picked from commit 01ae01ec26769d15059a45432c8accffc10f0da1)

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/ussuri

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/ussuri branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I94e34ecb7a1c9fef5b793bfe776af3b44a5c06c8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-panko refs/changes/14/724014/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update hacking version to 1.1.x

This commit updates hacking version in test-requirements
and fixes some related pep8 issues

Also ignores false positive bandit test
B105: hardcoded_password_string,
B106: hardcoded_password_funcarg
based on variable or argument names.
For more info refer [1][2]

[1] https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b105_hardcoded_password_string.html
[2] https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b106_hardcoded_password_funcarg.html

Change-Id: If779ebad11926594961577e0744093a8ba691610
Story: 2004930
Task: 29314
(cherry picked from commit 3404a6df722b8f85c425d15769a0e831891cdc2c)

added_lines: if facts[:operatingsystem] == 'Fedora' { :httpd_service_name => 'httpd', :httpd_ports_file => '/etc/httpd/conf/ports.conf', :wsgi_script_path => '/var/www/cgi-bin/zaqar', :wsgi_script_source => '/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/zaqar/transport/wsgi/app.py' } else if facts[:operatingsystemmajrelease] > '7' { :httpd_service_name => 'httpd', :httpd_ports_file => '/etc/httpd/conf/ports.conf', :wsgi_script_path => '/var/www/cgi-bin/zaqar', :wsgi_script_source => '/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/zaqar/transport/wsgi/app.py' } else { :httpd_service_name => 'httpd', :httpd_ports_file => '/etc/httpd/conf/ports.conf', :wsgi_script_path => '/var/www/cgi-bin/zaqar', :wsgi_script_source => '/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/zaqar/transport/wsgi/app.py' } end end

commit_message:
Add appendix for TrilioVault deployment

Add new appendix to cover deployment and configuration
of TrilioVault.

TrilioVault is a commericial, propriety product and is
not part of OpenStack, but is deployable using free and open
source charms which form part of the OpenStack Charms
project.

Change-Id: Ifdaf0ec7eec1ce790b79a17952621eeb8dc65d61
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-deployment-guide refs/changes/08/722808/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ======================================= Appendix T: TrilioVault Data Protection ======================================= Overview -------- As of the 20.05 release, the OpenStack charms support deployment of TrilioVault, a data protection solution that integrates with OpenStack. TrilioVault allows end-users to independently backup and restore point-in-time snapshots of their own workloads. .. note:: TrilioVault is not part of the OpenStack project and is a commercially supported propriety product. For more details visit `trilio.io`_. Prerequisites ------------- - Ubuntu 18.04 LTS - OpenStack Queens, Stein or Train - NFS server for storage of snapshots .. note:: TrilioVault requires a license to operate. For more details visiti `trilio.io`_. Deployment ---------- The TrilioVault solution consists of three core services: - TrilioVault Workload Manager: this service provides the main API for TrilioVault and is used to create and manage snapshots and restores. - TrilioVault Data Mover API: this service provides the API for managing the TrilioVault Data Mover services and is used by the TrilioVault Workload Manager. - TrilioVault Data Mover: deployed alongside Nova Compute services this service is responsible for managing the snapshot process for instances running on the OpenStack Cloud. TrilioVault also provides an OpenStack Dashboard plugin providing a Web UI for end users and cloud administrators. TrilioVault may be added to an OpenStack cloud using the following example overlay bundle: .. code-block:: yaml series: bionic applications: trilio-data-mover: charm: cs:~openstack-charmers/trilio-data-mover options: triliovault-pkg-source: "deb [trusted=yes] https://apt.fury.io/triliovault-python3/ /" trilio-dm-api: charm: cs:~openstack-charmers/trilio-dm-api num_units: 1 options: openstack-origin: cloud:bionic-train triliovault-pkg-source: "deb [trusted=yes] https://apt.fury.io/triliovault-python3/ /" trilio-horizon-plugin: charm: cs:~openstack-charmers-next/trilio-horizon-plugin options: triliovault-pkg-source: "deb [trusted=yes] https://apt.fury.io/triliovault-python3/ /" trilio-wlm: charm: cs:~openstack-charmers/trilio-wlm num_units: 1 options: openstack-origin: cloud:bionic-train triliovault-pkg-source: "deb [trusted=yes] https://apt.fury.io/triliovault-python3/ /" relations: - - trilio-horizon-plugin:dashboard-plugin - openstack-dashboard:dashboard-plugin - - trilio-dm-api:identity-service - keystone:identity-service - - trilio-dm-api:shared-db - mysql:shared-db - - trilio-dm-api:amqp - rabbitmq-server:amqp - - trilio-data-mover:amqp - rabbitmq-server:amqp - - trilio-data-mover:juju-info - nova-compute:juju-info - - trilio-wlm:shared-db - mysql:shared-db - - trilio-wlm:amqp - rabbitmq-server:amqp - - trilio-wlm:identity-service - keystone:identity-service After deployment completes the TrilioVault Data Mover and Workload Manager applications will be in a blocked state. Both must be configured with a valid NFS share on the NFS server used in the deployment via configuration: .. code-block:: bash juju config trilio-wlm nfs-shares=10.40.3.20:/srv/triliovault juju config trilio-data-mover nfs-shares=10.40.3.20:/srv/triliovault Both services must be configured with the same NFS share. The TrilioVault Workload Manager service configuration must then be completed using actions. The first step creates a cloud admin level trust for the trilio service account so that it can access resources from across users and projects for backups. This action requires that the cloud admin password setup by the keystone application be provided using the 'password' parameter: .. code-block:: bash juju run-action trilio-wlm/leader create-cloud-admin-trust password=cloudadminpassword Finally the TrilioVault deployment must be licensed; this is completed by uploading the license file from Trilio as a resource and then executing the 'create-license' action: .. code-block:: bash juju attach trilio-wlm license=mycorp_tv.lic juju run-action trilio-wlm/leader create-license After completing this steps the 'trilio-wlm' and 'trilio-data-mover' applications should be in the 'actiive' state and ready for use. .. LINKS .. _trilio.io: https://www.trilio.io/triliovault/openstack/

commit_message:
Move tempest-full-rocky-py3 job defintion to stackviz

tempest-full-rocky-py3 was defined in Tempest which is going
to removed[1] from there as rocky is in Extended Maintainance state.

Stackviz need to run the rocky job as it support py3.5 env also.

Renaming the job to avoid the zuul error of duplciate definition of same
job name.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/722183/1

commit_message:
Fix multiple issues

Multiple issues combined to pass CI

1. drop tripleo-common-tempest-plugin

This is not needed plugin without any branches or releases. And wants Python 3
while we have Py2 for CentOS 7.

Original Change-Id: I9cab91b82941ea125b16d19e68722ce41a1f11f2
14:41 < hrw> is  tripleo-common-tempest-plugin your stuff?
14:43 <@EmilienM> yes and it does nothing. I thought we removed that?
14:43 <@EmilienM> apparently it's still here https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-common-tempest-plugin
14:43 <@EmilienM> we should burn it, weshay|ruck ^
14:44 < hrw> EmilienM: also fine to drop from train?
14:44 <@EmilienM> burn it everywhere you can
14:44 < hrw> THANKS
14:44 <@EmilienM> it has never been useful
14:44 <@EmilienM> and people who started it left
14:48 <@weshay|ruck> EmilienM, yup

2. Sensu: Remove ceph and process-checks plugins from client

The sensu image became unbuildable, failing to install the ceph plugin:

    Unable to resolve dependencies: sensu-plugins-ceph requires english (= 0.6.3)

This has happened because the author of the 'english' gem has seen fit
to publish a new 0.7.0 release, and 'yank' [1] all previous releases
from rubygems.

This change removes the ceph and process-checks plugins, which both
suffer from a dependency on the yanked english 0.6.3.

[1] https://rubygems.org/gems/english/versions/0.6.3

Original Change-Id: I9d34413fa10b5a2920aca60b08141bfaddcc7415
Closes-Bug: #1871600
(cherry picked from commit 818dc4d6ff12a3119be072e0c68e2d2c8da9b799)
(cherry picked from commit 2d1017be3fd658011fc5a86bd38b7265da306ea3)

3. Use freezer queens releases

There are no freezer releases in Rocky, so these packages stayed on
master. This is now python 3 only, so fails to build. Pin to Queens
6.0.0 releases.

4. Pin elasticsearch gem to <7.6.0 in fluentd

Since the release of the elasticsearch 7.6.0 gem, the fluentd image
fails to build on Ubuntu due to a transitive dependency on faraday.

ERROR:  Error installing fluent-plugin-elasticsearch:
    faraday requires Ruby version >= 2.3.

Pin elasticsearch to <7.6.0.

Change-Id: I6200ed527244313107666753257f52d4b9305dd3

commit_message:
Add 20.05 release note for TrilioVault

This includes an upgrade note for deployments using prior Trilio
developed charm versions.

Change-Id: Ia402970218ac63830d6ed9647bdb52e4ab99eb6c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-guide refs/changes/59/724359/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * trilio-data-mover * trilio-dm-api * trilio-horizon-plugin * trilio-wlmTrilioVault support ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ New charms are provided for the deployment of TrilioVault providing an OpenStack integrated snapshot and restore service for workloads. For more details see the `TrilioVault appendix`_ in the `OpenStack Charms Deployment Guide`_. .. note:: TrilioVault is a commerical snapshot and restore solution for OpenStack and does not form part of the OpenStack project. TrilioVault Data Mover charm upgrade ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ For deployments using prior versions of the trilio-data-mover charm (as provided by Trilio) the relation between the trilio-data-mover charm and rabbitmq-server must be removed and re-added to ensure that specific access for the data-mover service is provided for RabbitMQ. .. code-block:: none juju remove-relation trilio-data-mover rabbitmq-server juju add-relation trilio-data-mover rabbitmq-server .. _TrilioVault appendix: https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/charm-deployment-guide/latest/app-trilio-vault.html

commit_message:
Add Github mirroring job to all official repos

Now that the Github repositories have been cleaned up of refs/changes
entries, we can enable per-repo mirroring globally.

Note that:
- openstack/release-test was already added as a test
- for repos that did not have an entry in projects.yaml, we create one

Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/718478
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/724329
Change-Id: Ia72b3271a65d38ea6b5e4ad03af5813193c47926

subject: Fix broken unit tests because of list in notification drivers
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-04-29 15:11:40.000000000', 'files': ['spec/classes/keystone_init_spec.rb'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/2adf1b852a2166bdb9bf42673335ba99374c20ac', 'message': 'Fix broken unit tests because of list in notification drivers

Because the value for oslo_messaging_notifications/driver is now
a list[1], we should expect that a list is set when multiple drivers
are given.

[1] c7b0cc82fac79b47c3dd9a625cbd5a1eb192ed00

Change-Id: I7f8c3c9ab72e7962e96464842b45f5b7946ea439
(cherry picked from commit 6382396f091616d85a2e372f1ebc3229ef24f286)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix broken unit tests because of list in notification drivers

Because the value for oslo_messaging_notifications/driver is now
a list[1], we should expect that a list is set when multiple drivers
are given.

[1] c7b0cc82fac79b47c3dd9a625cbd5a1eb192ed00

Change-Id: I7f8c3c9ab72e7962e96464842b45f5b7946ea439
(cherry picked from commit 6382396f091616d85a2e372f1ebc3229ef24f286)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone refs/changes/45/724345/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add official-openstack-repo-jobs project template

Add a project template for jobs attached to official and active
OpenStack repositories (like the GitHub mirroring).

Change-Id: I1004508c66d53a5e3c11af1e3dbf411338cfd25f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-zuul-jobs refs/changes/29/724329/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - project-template: name: official-openstack-repo-jobs description: | Jobs attached to official and active OpenStack repositories post: jobs: - openstack-upload-github-mirror

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-04-28 10:28:41.000000000', 'files': ['ironic_inspector/test/unit/test_migrations.py', 'ironic_inspector/test/unit/test_node_cache.py', 'ironic_inspector/test/unit/test_iptables.py', 'ironic_inspector/test/unit/test_manager.py', 'ironic_inspector/test/unit/test_common_ironic.py', 'ironic_inspector/test/unit/test_plugins_physnet_cidr_map.py', 'ironic_inspector/test/unit/test_introspect.py', 'ironic_inspector/test/unit/test_plugins_standard.py', 'ironic_inspector/test/unit/test_process.py', 'ironic_inspector/test/unit/test_plugins_local_link_connection.py', 'ironic_inspector/test/unit/test_plugins_lldp_basic.py', 'ironic_inspector/test/unit/test_plugins_pci_devices.py', 'ironic_inspector/test/unit/test_main.py', 'tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-inspector/commit/cee5922674a571e82632fbc2c25488ea10e903e0', 'message': "Hacking: enforce usage of autospec=True in tests

Using autospec ensures that mocked functions are called with correct
arguments, so it's highly desired to have it.

Change-Id: I9c8395adf852495d2ef6db732d727990e8abd5d7

commit_message:
Hacking: enforce usage of autospec=True in tests

Using autospec ensures that mocked functions are called with correct
arguments, so it's highly desired to have it.

Change-Id: I9c8395adf852495d2ef6db732d727990e8abd5d7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-inspector refs/changes/59/723859/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [H210] Require autospec, spec, or spec_set in mock.patch/mock.patch.object callsenable-extensions=H106,H203,H204,H205,H210,H904

subject: Rebuild reactive APIs for layer-basic regression
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-04-28 21:17:59.000000000', 'files': ['rebuild'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-gnocchi/commit/cb52db643e4103f1678e7231178eef913810ee2d', 'message': 'Rebuild reactive APIs for layer-basic regression

Fix regression in layer-basic which failed to unpack new dependencies
properly during the upgrade-charm hook.

Github Issue: #166
Closes Bug: #1875496

Change-Id: I680f276e255ddf667ccc228acbd88576661c6d26
'}]
commit_message:
Rebuild reactive APIs for layer-basic regression

Fix regression in layer-basic which failed to unpack new dependencies
properly during the upgrade-charm hook.

Github Issue: #166
Closes Bug: #1875496

Change-Id: I680f276e255ddf667ccc228acbd88576661c6d26
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-gnocchi refs/changes/70/724170/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Clean up orphan instances virt driver
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-04-01 07:44:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/950d6b1a97798616f6fa316b67e139425bfc3193', 'message': 'Clean up orphan instances virt driver

Delete the VM while the nove-compute service down, the instance
will become orphan and is not tracked by database anymore. Orphan
instances could still query from libvirt by name, then deleted or
power off by name.

This commit introduce libvirt driver support for adding new periodic
clean task to clean orphan instances.

Change-Id: Ia7618e11e727e84818874bf5b6fae802ff030609
Partial-Bug: #1820802

Delete the VM while the nove-compute service down, the instance
will become orphan and is not tracked by database anymore. Orphan
instances could still query from libvirt by name, then deleted or
power off by name.

commit_message:
Clean up orphan instances virt driver

The VM is not tracked by database could still query from libvirt
by UUID, then deleted or power off by UUID. This commit introduce
libvirt driver for periodicly clean the orphan instances.

Change-Id: Ia7618e11e727e84818874bf5b6fae802ff030609
Partial-Bug: #1820802

commit_message:
[NetApp] Fix share replica failing for 'transfer in progress' error

This patch fix an issue in NetApp driver share replica periodic
check that erroneuouly set a share replica to error after receiving
a 'Another transfer is in progress' error. The driver now skips the
resync operation for all expected transfer in progress relationship
status.

Closes-Bug: #1848889
Change-Id: If82aaa184db84660389f82654279f3c5b238fd51
(cherry picked from commit 572be43bb03a67376b52a11c70e587eb160b68a3)
(cherry picked from commit cc2dea14a514ad1a7025d904074307817c60e3ce)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/22/723622/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - | Fixed an issue in NetApp driver share replica periodic check that erroneously set a replica state to 'error'. In this routine, a SnapMirror resync operation was being triggered while the replica data transfering is still in progress, receiving an error from the storage side. The driver now skips resync operation for all in progress SnapMirror relationship status.

subject: [NetApp] Fix driver to honor standard extra specs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-04-11 02:22:00.000000000', 'files': ['manila/share/drivers/netapp/dataontap/cluster_mode/lib_base.py', 'releasenotes/notes/bug-1707084-netapp-manila-driver-to-honour-std-extra-specs-d32fae4e9411b503.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/commit/644e2cfc564208bd5b9b3e1201f8f9718ca65823', 'message': "[NetApp] Fix driver to honor standard extra specs

During migration and manage/unmanage operations, if we used standard
extra_specs format (e.g. 'thin_provisioning'='True') instead of
NetApp based extra_specs format (e.g. 'netapp:thin_provisioned'='True'),
NetApp driver used to ignore these standard extra_specs settings
and continued the operation with the default option.
The driver is now fixed to handle this issue by honouring the

Change-Id: I48f4d966201fc8d6bd6eec0c37f1575b434310e7
Closes-Bug: #1707084
(cherry picked from commit 9250e02b56fa4a0d93fe4c32cdfac4eceab8d095)
(cherry picked from commit 678ea79f85e53ec21a0fb74758875b3a7ebe1aa7)
"}]
commit_message:
[NetApp] Fix driver to honor standard extra specs

During migration and manage/unmanage operations, if we used standard
extra_specs format (e.g. 'thin_provisioning'='True') instead of
NetApp based extra_specs format (e.g. 'netapp:thin_provisioned'='True'),
NetApp driver used to ignore these standard extra_specs settings
and continued the operation with the default option.
The driver is now fixed to handle this issue by honouring the
standard extra_specs during migration and manage/unmanage.

Change-Id: I48f4d966201fc8d6bd6eec0c37f1575b434310e7
Closes-Bug: #1707084
(cherry picked from commit 9250e02b56fa4a0d93fe4c32cdfac4eceab8d095)
(cherry picked from commit 678ea79f85e53ec21a0fb74758875b3a7ebe1aa7)

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/ussuri

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/ussuri branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Icdde4120bc502c27391831321a96e01b9818aa95

commit_message:
[NetApp] Fix share shrink error status

This patch fixes the error raised by NetApp driver when the user try
to shrink a share to a size smaller than the current used space. Now
the driver raises "shrinking_possible_data_loss" instead of
"shrinking_error".

Change-Id: I01a549a0e299ae0d0d9b603a9d0797f16f4b68b3
Closes-Bug: #1858328
(cherry picked from commit c169902d41ef2b70ce1c1181408bc0916a7ea319)
(cherry picked from commit 97a913209825f975ccfc2d76c91f4215d02622ad)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/32/723632/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _mock_api_error(self, code='fake', message='fake'): return mock.Mock(side_effect=netapp_api.NaApiError(code=code, message=message)) def test_shrinking_possible_data_loss(self): naapi_error = self._mock_api_error(code=netapp_api.EVOLOPNOTSUPP, message='Possible data loss') vserver_client = mock.Mock() self.mock_object(self.library, '_get_vserver', mock.Mock(return_value=(fake.VSERVER1, vserver_client))) mock_set_volume_size = self.mock_object( vserver_client, 'set_volume_size', naapi_error) new_size = fake.SHARE['size'] - 1 self.assertRaises(exception.ShareShrinkingPossibleDataLoss, self.library.shrink_share, fake.SHARE, new_size) self.library._get_vserver.assert_called_once_with(share_server=None) mock_set_volume_size.assert_called_once_with(fake.SHARE_NAME, new_size)

commit_message:
Fix tenant_id for a new port.

To successfully create a port in a shared network which belongs
to a different tenant, the tenant of the new port should be same
as the tenant of a request user.

Closes-bug: #1815461
Change-Id: Ia243f213b23f3f34845de5d97e8eaa5aa6979e76
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/19/714019/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
fix bug in quota checking

When project quota set unlimited(-1), and user in the
project is limited to a value.Then project quota must
smaller than project usage when checking quotas, which
means the value 'overs' is not None.
In this case, even though the user not over the quota,
but they can not create share

Closes-bug: #1872872

Change-Id: Id9e2bcb5d30d2b81b0723dd296b537ac7d4519f2
(cherry picked from commit 780053968270900a1402fa0db4ae96bd16060ad4)
(cherry picked from commit 73837ce05a9bf07c7dd4e15c98eee511ff9e1a10)
(cherry picked from commit f2afb50fbbd6ec1b14ba93a64d292cbc66e53cfe)

commit_message:
tox: Keeping going with docs

1. Sphinx 1.8 introduced [1] the '--keep-going' argument which, as its name
suggests, keeps the build running when it encounters non-fatal errors.
This is exceptionally useful in avoiding a continuous edit-build loop
when undertaking large doc reworks where multiple errors may be
introduced.

2. Remove the py27 from tox since magnum already drop support python 2.7

[1] https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/commit/e3483e9b045

Change-Id: I6e713b51cf9fac87e696fdfce8156f656a0f1df5

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/ussuri

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/ussuri branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I637808fa6e19232a4702a486794db549340bf558

commit_message:
Adapt to Octavia Certificate Configuration Guide.

This patch updates the octavia controller deployment to use the
latest octavia certificate configuration guide [1]. The dual CA changes
were introduced in Train.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/octavia/latest/admin/guides/certificates.html

Change-Id: If89ec0d631568db70690f1a69d00115c59abe678
Closes-Bug: #1862133

commit_message:
Bump default tox env from py37 to py38

Python 3.8 is now our highest level supported python runtime.
This updates the default tox target environments to swap out
py37 for py38 to make sure local development testing is
covering this version.

This does not impact zuul jobs in any way, nor prevent local
tests against py37. It just changes the default if none is
explicitly provided.

Change-Id: I1992bad2ee6bffade2f937cc0d8dc6ae800f4159
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
[WIP] Driver Resource Specification

Spec for defining new resource that will represent driver
configurations with Magnum.

Change-Id: I73127c465e189bbe86749ac7efacbd9e0879e477
Implements: blueprint driver-resource
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum-specs refs/changes/49/439849/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =============== Driver Resource =============== Launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/magnum/+spec/driver-resource Provide a new Magnum versioned resource to represent the current configuration of a Magnum driver. Changes to the driver resource will be versioned and other operations such as cluster upgrade will be able to make use of the driver resources to determine what to upgrade. Operators will also be able to make use of the driver resources to constrain attributes per driver for cluster operations such as create, update, and upgrade. Problem description =================== Magnum driver plugins provide a method for implementing the Magnum cluster operations, but currently there not much option to provide configuration information without having to update the driver plugin itself which would require redeploying driver plugin files. Magnum operators would like to be able to limit cluster creation to defined supported values and/or ranges. Cluster Templates are currently used for this but are not closely attached to drivers and do not allow for ranges of acceptable values. Templates also do not have any versions to help with cluster creation history or change deltas when templates are updated. Magnum plans to add cluster upgrade functionality for Pike release. One need of the cluster upgrade feature is to determine what values are changed with the upgrade. Driver changes need to be represented within Magnum and be versioned to enable this feature. Proposed change =============== This spec proposes that we add a new resource to Magnum that will be called Driver. It will be stored in the Magnum database and will have several new APIs to create, delete, and update the Driver resource. This will be a versioned resource which will track updates made to the resource. Database changes ---------------- A new table will be added to the db to store the Driver objects. The Driver objects will have the following attributes: - uuid - name (string) - latest_version (integer) - plugin_name (string) - enabled (boolean) A new table will be added to store the DriverVersion objects. The DriverVersion objects will have the following attributes: - FK to Driver Object - version (integer) - public (boolean) - config (blob of JSON) - cluster_count (integer) API changes ----------- The following APIs will be added to interact with the Driver resource. This is represented in the form of CLI commands. Additional implementation details will be included in the submitted patches for the feature. **driver-create** - Create a Driver:: magnum driver-create <driver_name> <plugin_name> [--config <JSON blob>] \ [--public <value>] [--enabled <value>] Example: magnum driver-create my-k8s-driver k8s_fedora_atomic_v1 {config json blob} driver_name Positional, Required This specifies the name that will be used for this driver. plugin_name Positional, Required This specifies the name of the driver plugin that this driver resource will be used for. If no valid driver plugin is found matching the provided name then an error will be generated. --config Optional This will be a JSON blob that contains the configuration information for the driver. If no config is provided then this will be generated from the default configuration file included with each driver plugin. --public Optional If set to 'True' then this Driver resource will be viewable and usable by all users of Magnum. By default, this value will be set to 'False'. --enabled Optional This value will be set to 'True' by default. If set to false then clusters will not be able to be created using this driver until it is enabled. **driver-update** - Update a Driver to a new version:: magnum driver-update <driver_name or UUID> [--config < newJSON blob>] \ [--public <new value>] [--enabled <new value>] Example: magnum driver-update my-k8s-driver --enabled false driver_name or UUID Positional, Mandatory A valid Driver name/UUID --config Optional This will be a JSON blob that contains the configuration information for the driver. It will replace the existing config entry for this driver. --public Optional If set to 'True' then this Driver resource will be viewable and usable by all users of Magnum. --enabled Optional This value will be set to 'True' by default. If set to false then clusters will not be able to be created using this driver until it is enabled. **driver-delete** - Delete a Driver:: magnum driver-delete <driver_name or UUID> Example: magnum driver-delete my-k8s-driver driver_name or UUID Positional, Mandatory A valid Driver name/UUID A delete will verify that cluster_count is 0 on all versions before a delete will be successful. Alternatives ------------ Update ClusterTemplate to have the following: - versions - specify ranges instead of single values on attributes - add a Magnum setting to limit cluster create to require ClusterTemplates and not allow template value overrides outside ranges The same functionality could be accomplished using ClusterTemplates. The cons of this would be that the UX of templates would be more complicated with it trying to be responsible for many different things(simplified parameters, operator parameter enforcement, driver config, etc...). The main proposal keeps ClusterTemplates focused on the UX for simplified parameters. The more operator focused driver configuration options are now moved to a separate resource. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Pike - TBD Work Items ---------- Dependencies ============ None Security Impact =============== None

commit_message:
Improve VLAN allocations synchronization

In order to reduce the number of elements retrieved from the DB, this
patch, before processing the VLAN allocations per physical network,
deleted those registers belonging to any unconfigured physical network.

The VLAN registers per physical network are deleted using a bulk delete
operation, to speed up the process.

Those missing VLAN registers per network are now created using a bulk
insert operation, available in the ORM. This bulk operation speeds up
the sync process.

Change-Id: I8568e2277e157754aaff87a059a40e34e6a43e2b
Partial-Bug: #1862178
(cherry picked from commit 016e7826f165e69c3956375fc3aa8b8d642c9dc9)
(cherry picked from commit 651eb12bec5e5e986bed79f3a5c006c617e79bda)

commit_message:
Bump default tox env from py37 to py38

Python 3.8 is now our highest level supported python runtime.
This updates the default tox target environments to swap out
py37 for py38 to make sure local development testing is
covering this version.

This does not impact zuul jobs in any way, nor prevent local
tests against py37. It just changes the default if none is
explicitly provided.

Change-Id: Id0107e9cdabbc1435c709641b93cb5c90cdf6907
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Cleanup py27 support

This repo is now testing only with Python 3, so let's make
a few cleanups:
- Remove obsolete sections from setup.cfg
- Update requirements, no need for python_version anymore
- Cleanup doc/source/conf.py to remove now obsolete content.
- Use newer openstackdocstheme and sphinx versions
- Update constraints URL

Change-Id: I71fad2f2287477ae570ae40a8705b035bbc6a38e

subject: Retry after hitting libvirt error VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID in live migration.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-10-22 07:51:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/383b25d7800c7212616cf8b3f20178ca657aa943', 'message': "Retry after hitting libvirt error VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID in live migration.

When migration of a persistent guest completes, the guest merely shuts off,
but libvirt unhelpfully raises an VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID error code, in the
nova code, we pretend this case means success. But if we are in the middle of a
live migration, and sadly qemu-kvm process is killed accidentally,
such as by host OOM, which happens rarely in our environment but it does happen few
times, domain state is SHUTOFF and then we will get VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID
while trying to call `self._domain.jobStats()`. Under the circumstance,
migration should be considered failed, otherwise post_live_migration() function
starts to clean up instance files and we will lose customers' data forever.

In this patch, we `pretend` the migration job is still running after
hitting VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID and retry to get job stats for a few times,
which the count of retries can be configured. Because if migration succeeds
finally, we won't get VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID after some retries,
but the error code still happens if qemu-kvm process is killed accidentally.

Change-Id: I94aeda2156cd95e87b62da28e8b16cf7c1950a14
Closes-bug: #1799152
Signed-off-by: Fan Zhang <zh.f@outlook.com>
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2018-10-23 02:47:59.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/92b7ad62f6bd4b72e2b8996dd4f01413488621aa', 'message': 'Retry after hitting libvirt error VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID in live migration.

To avoid rare condition such as while live migration job is still
running, qemu-kvm is killed accidentally, and nova thinks the job
is done, then post live migration starts to clean instance files,
this patch proposes such changes:

1.Do not treat VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID as migration job completed.
2.`Pretend` the migration job is still running after hitting
  VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID by returning VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_UNBOUNDED for
  a few times.
3.Number of retries can be configured by CONF.job_info_retry_count.

Change-Id: I94aeda2156cd95e87b62da28e8b16cf7c1950a14
Closes-bug: #1799152
Signed-off-by: Fan Zhang <zh.f@outlook.com>
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2018-10-24 10:53:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/d6af44fec3e65b13e02ae301a38adcd5f3a1ebc7', 'message': 'Retry after hitting libvirt error VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID in live migration.

To avoid rare condition such as while live migration job is still
running, qemu-kvm is killed accidentally, and nova thinks the job
is done, then post live migration starts to clean instance files,

commit_message:
Retry after hitting libvirt error VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID in live migration.

To avoid rare condition such as while live migration job is still
running, qemu-kvm is killed accidentally, and nova thinks the job
is done, then post live migration starts to clean instance files,
this patch proposes such changes:

1.Do not treat VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID as migration job completed.
2.`Pretend` the migration job is still running after hitting
  VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID by returning VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_UNBOUNDED for
  a few times.
3.Number of retries can be configured by CONF.job_info_retry_count.

Change-Id: I94aeda2156cd95e87b62da28e8b16cf7c1950a14
Closes-bug: #1799152
Signed-off-by: Fan Zhang <zh.f@outlook.com>

commit_message:
CI: fix kayobe-tox-molecule job

The kayobe-tox-molecule job is currently failing on stable/train and
earlier branches. This was caused by the 13.0 release of the 'sh'
package [1]. A 13.1 release fixed this for Python 3, but there is no fix
available for Python 2 currently.

This change works around the issue by pinning 'sh' to <13.0 in
test-requirements.txt.

[1] https://github.com/ansible-community/molecule/issues/2676

Change-Id: I0df1dadb3b48736cdbd25112517e524533550210
(cherry picked from commit 5f836518cfe964d2733f5a7db327fbfad3b8e8b0)

commit_message:
Explicitly install inspector-dnsmasq package

The package used to be implicitly pulled before [1],
now this needs to be installed explicitly.

Changed inspector_package param to contain list of packages
to install and adopted package module to handle list
of packages.

[1] https://review.rdoproject.org/r/#/c/23761/

Change-Id: I2435b476b65be5aab6e35bad0834e60dc9c8ced5

commit_message:
Rebuild reactive APIs for layer-basic regression

Fix regression in layer-basic which failed to unpack new dependencies
properly during the upgrade-charm hook.

Github Issue: #166
Closes Bug: #1875496

commit_message:
Update master for stable/ussuri

stable/ussuri.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on

Release ironic-prometheus-exporter for ussuri

This is the final release for ironic-prometheus-exporter for the ussuri
cycle.

Please leave +1 if this is ready to go, or -1 if the team needs a
little more time. If so, update this path with the new commit
hash to use once ready.

Patches with no response will be processed soon after the April
23 deadline.

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

Now that we no longer support py27, we can use the standard library
unittest.mock module instead of the third party mock lib.

Change-Id: I6db222d0c9aab7c880fcadd3fa6f24d938b12307
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add NeutronDhcpAgentDnsmasqEnableAddr6List param

Add boolean parameter ``NeutronDhcpAgentDnsmasqEnableAddr6List``
to support the ``dnsmasq_enable_addr6_list`` option in dhcp
agent settings.

Related-Bug: #1861032
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/704436
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/710335
Change-Id: I69651b7e3390b5239097a9638ac1dc83a12fe96f

commit_message:
Add "--labels-override" boolean option when creating a cluster

If "--label-override" is present, labels passwd with "cluster-create"
will be used, rather than labels retrieved from template, just like
current behaviour. If "--label-override" isn't present, labels retrieved
from template will be updated, if a label doesn't exit in template,
it will be added into labels passed to create cluster

Change-Id: Icbbd980148a33082339c51842c62b067132fce65
Task: 22202
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-magnumclient refs/changes/94/621994/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @utils.arg('--labels-override', metavar='<lables-override>', type=bool, default=False, help=_('Override labels from template or not. The default is ' 'False, which will update labels rather than override it')) if args.labels is not None: opts['labels'] = magnum_utils.handle_labels(args.labels) if not args.labels_override: template_lables = dict(cluster_template.labels) opts['labels'] = template_lables.update(opts['labels'])
deleted_lines: if args.labels is not None: opts['labels'] = magnum_utils.handle_labels(args.labels)

subject: Allow overriding template labels on create
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-12-03 15:48:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/magnum/commit/f789f262b29e8cc082fbb204fda3d6f8033faf2a', 'message': "Allow overriding template labels on create

Allow overriding cluster template labels at cluster creation time. This
is done using a prefix '++' on the label name. As an example for
override:
openstack coe cluster template create ... \
    --labels label1=value1,label2=value2
openstack coe cluster create ... \
    --labels ++label1=value111,++label3=value3

In this example we override an existing value (label1), add a new label
not on the original template list (label3) and take the value of the
original template label (label2).

The previous behavior where no prefix '++' is given for any of the
labels is kept, with cluster labels taking over all labels from the
template.

One assumption is that if one value is overriden, then all values not
overriden are taken from the template. We could trigger an error if
necessary for something like:
openstack coe cluster create --labels ++label1=value111,label2=value2
( not no prefix ++ on label2 )

or simply document this behavior.

commit_message:
Allow overriding template labels on create

Allow overriding cluster template labels at cluster creation time. This
is done using a prefix '++' on the label name. As an example for
override:
openstack coe cluster template create ... \
    --labels label1=value1,label2=value2
openstack coe cluster create ... \
    --labels ++label1=value111,++label3=value3

In this example we override an existing value (label1), add a new label
not on the original template list (label3) and take the value of the
original template label (label2).

The previous behavior where no prefix '++' is given for any of the
labels is kept, with cluster labels taking over all labels from the
template.

One assumption is that if one value is overriden, then all values not
overriden are taken from the template. We could trigger an error if
necessary for something like:
openstack coe cluster create --labels ++label1=value111,label2=value2
( not no prefix ++ on label2 )

or simply document this behavior.

Change-Id: I933942372c69614b8c80eee6f56444f1d6152a98
Task: 22202
Story: 2002591
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/11/621611/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: else: # Prefix ++ means the cluster template label should be overriden override_dict = {} for key, value in cluster.labels.__dict__: if key.startswith('++'): override_dict[key[2:]] = value # For consistency if one value is overriden, then all should and we # rely on template values for the remaining ones. If no override # is given, then only the explicit cluster labels are kept if len(override_dict) > 0: cluster.labels = cluster_template.labels for key, value in override_dict: cluster.labels.__setattr__(key, value)

commit_message:
Add spec for heat template changes for Nodegroups

blueprint nodegroups-heat

Change-Id: I2c763151a03fb8a6f26989ad254719895cf86dff
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum-specs refs/changes/80/433680/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================================== Changes to heat stacks for NodeGroups ===================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/magnum/+spec/nodegroups-heat NodeGroups support will require changes to the heat templates in the currently supported cluster drivers. Problem description =================== Supporting the NodeGroup resource in magnum will allow management of groups of nodes instead of being limited to one set of master nodes and worker nodes. Right now, the heat templates in the cluster drivers have this same limitation. Proposed change =============== Note: This spec does not seek to cover all of the necessary changes to stacks, but instead outline the approach to be used. Modify the cluster drivers to use a templating engine, such as Jinja, to dynamically generate the template that will be sent to heat. **Template structure** Since heat templates are declarative, the order of individual resources, parameters, and outputs doesn't matter as long as they are consistent. That is, at the template level, NodeGroups can be freely added and removed as long as other NodeGroups don't change and don't depend on them. Example cluster.yaml template (using Jinja2 syntax):: heat_template_version: ... description: ... parameters: # cluster-wide parameters ssh_key_name: ... external_network: ... {% for param in params %} # includes multiple params per NodeGroup {{ param }} {% endfor %} resources: # cluster-wide resources network: ... api_lb: ... {% for resource in resources %} # can include multiple resources per NG {{ resource }} {% endfor %} outputs: # cluster-wide outputs api_address: ... registry_address: ... {% for output in outputs %} # can include multiple outputs per NG {{ output }} {% endfor %} The above example assumes that not all nodegroups will have params/resources/outputs with identical structure, so it inserts the entire content of each. The values of these can come from template snippets themselves. For example, a NodeGroup resource could look like this, which would be processed and inserted into the above template:: {{ uuid }}: type: OS::Heat::ResourceGroup depends_on: - network properties: count: {get_param: {{ nodegroup_{{ uuid }}_count }} } removal_policies: - {resource_list: {get_param: nodegroup_{{ uuid }}_to_remove }} resource_def: type: kubeminion.yaml properties: ssh_key_name: {get_param: ssh_key_name} server_image: {get_param: nodegroup_{{ uuid }}_image} minion_flavor: {get_param: nodegroup_{{ uuid }}_flavor} ... The above example keeps the current heat template parameters. Since the template is being generated on the fly, some or all of the parameters could be dropped and the values inserted at this step. For example:: server_image: {{ image }} It doesn't make any difference to heat. As can be seen above, the generated templates will retain a structure almost exactly like they are now, just with a variable number of resources for NodeGroups. Whether or not any NodeGroups are present, the parent template will contain networking, load balancers, security groups, and anything else that pertains to the whole cluster. Template snippets will provide the parameters, resources, and outputs that belong to individual NodeGroups. **Managing NodeGroups in a cluster** Cluster stacks can exist without any NodeGroups. This doesn't create any major architectural problems in the heat templates since none of the networking or the load balancing resources depend on the master or worker nodes. There will be some edge cases when it comes to outputs. For example, in a cluster without a master load balancer there will be no API address available until a master nodegroup is created. The logic around when and what NodeGroups can be added/removed should be up to the individual drivers, but typically a master NodeGroup will need to be the first to be created and last to be removed. This is because the workers have dependencies on the masters. Addition or removal of NodeGroups should be fairly straightforward, since nothing else depends on them. The complexity of passing information between resources is handled automatically by heat, so as long as the templates are written correctly it will all work. There is no constraint on the number of resources added or removed per operation. A cluster including masters and workers can be created all at once (i.e. one request to heat) just like it is now, and any number of nodegroups can be added/removed in one operation. With heat's convergence engine, there isn't even any need to make users wait until stack create/update operations are complete; heat can now handle updates to a stack that is still in progress. Alternatives ------------ Separate heat stacks per NodeGroup. In this alternative, there would be a stack to represent the Cluster and a stack for each NodeGroup. Drivers would not need to generate templates, but instead manage passing information to and from the individual stacks, which is basically what heat is already designed to do. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- TBD Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: pike-3 Work Items ---------- .. TODO Dependencies ============ .. TODO Security Impact =============== None

commit_message:
Add NodeGroup overview specification

This spec was divided from the orginal NodeGroup spec. This
spec will cover a general overview of the new NodeGroup resource
and usage examples. CLI details for NodeGroups will follow in a
separate spec.

Change-Id: I89648c65d6e44aa349e4bc85c08451677c49e95d
Co-Authored-By: Drago Rosson <drago.rosson@rackspace.com>
Implements: blueprint nodegroups
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum-specs refs/changes/22/425422/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================== Individual Management of Node Groups ==================================== Launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/magnum/+spec/nodegroups Heterogeneous container clusters enable interesting use-cases that are impossible on clusters where all nodes are configured the same. For example, workloads that require differing amounts of memory, I/O, or processing power can be placed on the nodes that best fit them. NOTE: Unless specified otherwise, "Cluster" and "ClusterTemplate" refer to the v2 (new) versions. Problem Description =================== Magnum currently only supports creating uniform clusters. v1 Clusters+ClusterTemplates are monolithic resources with a mix of attributes that are either relevant to the cluster as a whole, the master nodes, or the worker nodes. To enable heterogeneous clusters, clusters must be split into multiple resources that represent the different parts of a cluster. Use Cases ========= 1. Heterogeneous clusters. Users will be able to create clusters that have multiple node configurations in them. Containers can be deployed to the node type that best fits them. 2. Clusters with nodes in multiple availability zones. 3. Composability. Breaking clusters into components that can work together allows them to be combined in more interesting and powerful ways. Each one can then be managed by users individually, giving them greater control. 4. Maintainability. As more complex use-cases for magnum emerge, having components that better represent the clusters that magnum creates will make it easier to add features because it will be clear what each component should be responsible for. Proposed Change =============== 1. Split Clusters into two resource types: Cluster and NodeGroup. **Cluster** Represents the cluster as a whole and acts as a "parent" for NodeGroups. It holds attributes that define the cluster as a whole such as networking information and what cluster driver to use. The cluster can also contain values that will be used as defaults for the underlying NodeGroups. If a NodeGroup does not define an attribute that is defined in the Cluster, then the value from the Cluster is copied into the NodeGroup. For example, the keypair may exist in the Cluster and will be used by any NodeGroup that is added, but if a NodeGroup is in a different region it may need to use a separate keypair. This would be done by specifying the new keypair when creating the NodeGroup representing that region. Clusters can have zero or more NodeGroups. See Data Model Impact for attributes that will change from v1 to v2. See NodeGroups Heat blueprint [1] for details on how Clusters will now be represented with Heat stacks. **NodeGroup** Represents a group of nodes that all have the same configuration. NodeGroups must always belong to a single cluster, and a cluster can have multiple NodeGroups. NodeGroups hold attributes that characterize the group of nodes, such as node count, and those which define the configuration of a node, such as flavor, image, and Docker volume size. See Data Model Impact for attributes. See NodeGroups Heat blueprint [2] for details on how NodeGroups will be represented with Heat stacks. **NodeGroup operations** See REST API Impact for definitions of commands and examples. Design Principles ================= No impact Alternatives ============ None currently suggested Data Model Impact ================= NOTE: This spec assumes changes from the flatten attributes spec: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/magnum/+spec/flatten-attributes Magnum's data model would be modified by the new division of information between Clusters and NodeGroups. Existing Clusters would be migrated to the new model to be represented in the form of Clusters + NodeGroups. A current Cluster will become a Cluster with 2 NodeGroups (1 master, 1 minion). **Changes to current set of Cluster/ClusterTemplate Attributes** A major goal of the v2 data model is to maintain backwards compatibility with v1's so that the v2 data model can still be driven by the v1 API (see REST API Impact for more details) and the v1 data model can be migrated to v2, rather than maintaining v1 and v2 in parallel for multiple cycles. Therefore, it is important to make it clear where each v1 attribute is going to end up in v2. v1 Cluster: ======================= ========== Database Field Fate ----------------------- ---------- id uuid project_id user_id name stack_id status status_reason api_address trust_id trustee_username trustee_user_id trustee_password coe_version container_version ca_cert_ref magnum_cert_ref cluster_template_id * FK to ClusterAttributes node_addresses Move to NG master_addresses Remove ======================= ========== * In previous iterations, cluster_template_id was marked for removal. With the versioning spec, that is no longer true. v1 ClusterTemplate: No changes have to be made to ClusterTemplate. v1 ClusterAttributes: ===================== ========== Database Field Fate --------------------- ---------- apiserver_port create_timeout discovery_url external_network_id fixed_network fixed_subnet network_driver volume_driver dns_nameserver coe http_proxy https_proxy no_proxy registry_enabled tls_disabled insecure_registry master_lb_enabled floating_ip_enabled keypair_id Copy to NG labels Copy to NG node_count Move to NG image_id Move to NG flavor_id Move to NG docker_volume_size Move to NG docker_storage_driver Move to NG cluster_distro Move to NG server_type Move to NG master_flavor_id Remove master_count Remove ===================== ========== **v2 Cluster table** - id - uuid - project_id - user_id - name - stack_id - status - status_reason - api_address - trust_id - trustee_username - trustee_user_id - trustee_password - coe_version - container_version - ca_cert_ref - magnum_cert_ref - cluster_template_id - FK to ClusterAttributes **v2 ClusterTemplate table** - id - uuid - project_id - user_id - name - public - FK to ClusterAttributes **v2 ClusterAttribute table** - apiserver_port - create_timeout - discovery_url - external_network (was external_network_id) - fixed_network - fixed_subnet - network_driver - volume_driver - dns_nameserver - coe - http_proxy - https_proxy - no_proxy - registry_enabled - tls_disabled - insecure_registry - master_lb_enabled - floating_ip_enabled - labels - keypair (was keypair_id) - This will be used as the default keypair if a NodeGroup does not specify its own. **v2 NodeGroup table** - id - uuid - project_id - user_id - name - stack_id - status - status_reason - node_addresses - FK to NodeGroupAttributes - FK to Cluster - ID of the Cluster the NodeGroup is associated with. **v2 NodeGroupTemplate table** - id - uuid - project_id - user_id - name - public - FK to NodeGroupAttributes - FK to ClusterTemplate - Not required to be set. ID of the ClusterTemplate the NGT is associated with. **v2 NodeGroupAttributes table** - labels - image (was image_id) - flavor (was flavor_id) - docker_volume_size - docker_storage_driver - node_distro (was cluster_distro) - server_type - node_count - keypair (was keypair_id) - During creation of a NG, if it's not already filled in and not specified during the create request, this value will be pulled from the Cluster the NG is a part of. - is_master (new attribute) - Boolean, indicates this NG is a master NG. - external_network (was external_network_id) - fixed_network - fixed_subnet - floating_ip_enabled - dns_nameserver - trust_id - trustee_username - trustee_user_id - trustee_password REST API Impact =============== This change would lead to a new v2 of the magnum API. The Current API would continue in v1 for legacy support. This would be implemented as a new pecan controller and section within the magnum API service. The magnum python client would also be impacted due to API changes and new commands around the new functionality. The magnum UI would need to be updated. Below are the basic nodegroup related API's that will be added. Details on these APIs and changes to existing APIs around NodeGroups for v2 can be found in the nodegroups-cli.rst spec. NodeGroup operations -------------------- **nodegroup-create** - Creates a NodeGroup and adds it to existing cluster:: magnum nodegroup-create <Cluster name or UUID> <NodeGroup definition> **nodegroup-update** - Modifies an existing NodeGroup:: magnum nodegroup-update [Cluster name or UUID] <NodeGroup name or UUID> \ [--<attribute> <new value> ...] \ [--clear <attribute> ...] **nodegroup-restart** - Triggers the restart of COE services on each node in a NodeGroup:: magnum nodegroup-restart [Cluster name or UUID] <NodeGroup name or UUID> **nodegroup-delete** - Deletes a NodeGroup:: magnum nodegroup-delete [Cluster name or UUID] <NodeGroup name or UUID> NodeGroupTemplate operations ---------------------------- **nodegroup-template-create** - Creates a NodeGroupTemplate:: magnum nodegroup-template-create [ClusterTemplate name or UUID] \ [--no-defaults] [--public] \ <NodeGroup definition> **nodegroup-template-update** - Updates one or more attributes on an existing NodeGroupTemplate:: magnum nodegroup-template-update [ClusterTemplate name or UUID] \ <NodeGroupTemplate name or UUID> \ [--<attribute>=<new value> ...] \ [--clear <attribute> ...] **nodegroup-template-delete** - Deletes one or more existing NodeGroupTemplates:: magnum nodegroup-template-delete [ClusterTemplate name or UUID] \ <NodeGroupTemplate name or UUID> Security Impact =============== A new API version will mean new endpoints and additional testing needed to maintain current security. The expectation is that all changes will meet current security goals and controls. Notifications Impact ==================== Current notifications will remain the same for Clusters. Additional notifications for NodeGroups could be added in a future update if desired. Other End-user Impact ===================== Sample use cases for users. These are sample CLI examples to show common NodeGroup usages. The purpose is to show examples of how nodegroups could be used, not to go into detail on proposed CLI implementation. Details on CLI usage can be found in nodegroups-cli.rst spec along with more examples. **Kubernetes with identical nodes** This use case matches a simple kubernetes cluster in Magnum today. Master and minion nodes are all of the same type. Option 1:: magnum nodegroup-template-create k8s-nodegroup-template \ --image fedora-atomic-latest \ --flavor m1.small \ --docker-volume-size 5 \ --node-count 1 magnum cluster-template-create k8s-cluster-template \ --external-network public \ --dns-nameserver 8.8.8.8 \ --network-driver flannel \ --coe kubernetes \ --master-nodegroup k8s-nodegroup-template \ --nodegroup k8s-nodegroup-template \ --node-count 2 magnum cluster-create k8s-cluster \ --cluster-template k8s-cluster-template **Kubernetes with 3 node group types** This example covers a use case where the user wants to setup their cluster with nodes that have 3 different types. They want the master to be of one type, have a base minion node type, and then a SSD minion node type. Here is one possible set of commands to create this:: magnum nodegroup-template-create k8s-master-ngt \ --image fedora-atomic-latest \ --flavor m1.small \ --docker-volume-size 5 \ --node-count 1 \ --master True magnum nodegroup-template-create k8s-base-minion-ngt \ --image fedora-atomic-latest \ --flavor m1.small \ --docker-volume-size 5 \ --node-count 4 magnum nodegroup-template-create k8s-ssd-minion-ngt \ --image fedora-atomic-latest \ --flavor m1.small.ssd \ --docker-volume-size 5 \ --node-count 2 magnum cluster-template-create k8s-cluster-template \ --external-network public \ --dns-nameserver 8.8.8.8 \ --network-driver flannel \ --coe kubernetes --master-nodegroup k8s-master-ngt \ --nodegroup k8s-base-minion-ngt \ --nodegroup k8s-ssd-minion-ngt \ magnum cluster-create k8s-cluster \ --cluster-template k8s-cluster-template **Managing the cluster** Add another ssd node:: magnum nodegroup-update k8s-cluster k8s-ssd-minion-ngt --node-count=3 Add a new larger flavor node group (add 5 nodes):: magnum nodegroup-template-create k8s-large-minion-ngt \ --image fedora-atomic-latest \ --flavor m1.large \ --docker-volume-size 5 \ --node-count 5 magnum nodegroup-create k8s-cluster \ --nodegroup-template k8s-large-minion-ngt Remove a nodegroup from cluster:: magnum nodegroup-delete k8s-cluster k8s-large-minion-ngt Create template from current cluster for future use:: magnum cluster-template-create MyNewClusterTemplate \ --from-cluster k8s-cluster This command would create a ClusterTemplate that had all current attributes of the "cloned" template, including NodeGroup templates. A new instance of the cluster could be created then by:: magnun cluster-create new-k8s-cluster \ --cluster-template MyNewClusterTemplate If no ClusterTemplate is needed to be stored a new cluster can be cloned directly from an existing cluster:: magnum cluster-create cloned-k8s-cluster --from-cluster k8s-cluster Update a template:: magnum cluster-template-update k8s-cluster-template --keypair=testkey magnum nodegroup-template-update k8s-minion-ngt --node-count=5 magnum nodegroup-template-update k8s-cluster-template --clear keypair Performance Impact ================== API changes should have minor performance impact. Heat stack changes will need to be tested to verify no major performance impact. Other Deployer Impact ===================== No Impact Developer Impact ================ NodeGroups, v2 API, attribute flattening, template changes, and Heat stack changes will be major changes to Magnum. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- See blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/magnum/+spec/nodegroups Work Items ---------- See blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/magnum/+spec/nodegroups Dependencies ============ Attribute flattening spec: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/magnum/+spec/flatten-attributes Heat Stack spec: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/magnum/+spec/nodegroups-heat Testing ======= Existing tests will need to be updated for database, conductor, cluster driver, and v1 api changes. In addition, new tests will need to be added for all v2 APIs. Since existing Clusters will be migrated to a new datamodel, Magnum upgrade testing will also need to be added. Documentation Impact ==================== New API documentation will be added for v2 that will include information on how NodeGroup work. The quickstart guide will also be updated to include usages of the new NodeGroup features. References ========== [1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/magnum/+spec/nodegroups-heat [2] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/magnum/+spec/flatten-attributes
